DISS_description.DISS_title: A Bio-informed Mechanical Gripping System for Use in a Soft Climbing Robot

DISS_institution.DISS_inst_name: Tufts University (Graduate Studies Arts, Sciences and Engineering)

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The mounting interest in climbing soft robots is rooted in the numerous potential applications for such technology, ranging from inspecting crop fields, navigating disaster zones, and space exploration. One of the most crucial criteria for a climbing robot is its ability to adhere to the surface [1]. Caterpillars, such as Manduca sexta, the Tobacco Hornworm, are among the most successful, soft bodied climbing herbivores on the planet [2]. Manduca has crochets (French for “hooks”) on each abdominal proleg that passively grip to complex branched substrates [3]. Several robotic applications have been inspired by caterpillars [54-61], but none emulate the mechanical gripping system that contributes to their versatility and adaptability in nature.

The present work describes Manduca’s unique gripping mechanism, and details the development of a passive, compliant gripping system that is omnidirectional and maximizes overall robustness. Moreover, using biology as the default whenever possible, this biologically informed research indirectly works to answer the question of why Manduca sexta has evolved the way it has and how that knowledge can infuse with current and future soft robotics engineering.
Keywords: caterpillars, Manduca sexta, gripping, gripping mechanism, soft robotics, climbing
